interpretation.p: All digital surrogates of the original source are linked with the markup textfile.
All Gaelic (and English) texts have an English summary, index terms, keywords, and, where applicable, a taxonomic reference.
For some Gaelic (and English) texts a bibliographic reference(s) will be provided to other sources.

correction.p: Errors from the original source transcription have been kept to a minimum by employing stringent quality control procedures. In addition, all texts have been proof‐read by the text editors.

A guiding principle of the Alexander Carmichael notebooks markup procedure is to approximate the original document as closely as possible, so that the character of Carmichael's transcriptions is preserved along with its content. XML (eXtensible Markup Language), with its capacity to convey emendations such as deletions (crossed out) and supralinear additions and so forth, can digitally reproduce an authentic version which reflects the source documents.
Where authorial changes, e.g. substitution, have occurred in the text then this has been annotated.
Where there are errors they have been corrected and words which were difficulty to decipher has been indicated

In such cases missing words or letters have been supplied. Quotation marks and other missing grammatical marks have in the main not been supplied. Where there are gaps in the text usually because the word was inaudible (some background noise, perhaps) or where the transcriber could not make out what was being said in the act of transcription (perhaps the speaker was inarticulate or mumbling or for whatever reason) then these have been tagged, though not explained; where a word is now difficult, illegible or just unclear, then this has also been tagged.
All such changes have been annotated in accordance with TEI 5 procedures.

normalization.p: No normalization of the words such as changing the source text to conform with current Gaelic orthographic conventions has been undertaken. The texts are as given with only minor editorial changes. in order to preserve the integrity of the original texts.

quotation.p: All opening quotation marks, hyphens, dashes, apostrophes, periods, colons, etc. have been retained in the source text and have been encoded in accodance with ISO entity references, etc.
All double marks have been processed using straight quotation marks, that is, ". All single quotation marks have been rendered using apostrophe.

hyphenation.p: End‐of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.

segmentation.p: Folio numbers have been added in pencil at the top of each notebook page are retained using the pb (pagebreak) element together with the n attribute for the page number and the ed attribute to specify the edition.
When an tale‐text or song which, more often than not, fills more than one page, it is segmented with page break.

langUsage.language: Approximately 40% of the fieldnote and transcription bokos are Scottish Gaelic, and the remaining 60% consist of English or Scots, along with stray quotations in Latin.

div.title:
The Bards and Bardism
of the Highlands
div.p:
The task to investigate the origin of
poetry would be as fruitless as it is un-
necessary. But we may reasonably believe
that like other arts, itpoetry did not come into
full maturity all at once. All nations
have their poets and I believe even the most
savage that have yet been discovered have their
war-songs and war dances. Poetry like
its twin sister music has a most an in-
describable power over the human heart. Nor
is this power confined to the human heart alone. The
animal kingdom is greatly under the in
fluence of poetry and song. The noble war
horse is delighted at the sound of the bugle a
and times his pace with to the notes thereof. I
need hardly mention to a Highland audience
the power of music over cattle. In many
of the folds over the Highalnds the milk-
maids are so accustomed to sing their
lilts and lays to the cows when milking
them that the cows will not give the milk
without. Nay it is even said that some
particular cows evince a partiality
for some particular songs by giving
the milk more freely. Even the gentle
timid sheep are fond of music. A noble
Highland baronet who has an estate
near London transported a flock of
black faced sheep to his EEstate some years
ago. The baronet is himself is deemed
one of the best pipers of the day. He or
his piper is in the daily habit of going
out to the parks to play to the sheep. When-
ever the sheep hear the pipes they come
scampering along till the whole flock
is around the piper player. I was
told by one who had seen this novel sight
that the sheep appeared delighted and played
and capered about like lambs. Birds we know
are l delightful melodists. Of all the birds
that visit our climate perhaps the song
of the sky-lark is the most cheering and
delightful.

The Celtic races have always been noted
for their love for poetry and music.
The Island of Skye was noted in ancient times
noted its colleges for military training
music and poetry. In the parish
of Sleat are very old ruins once where
not only the youths of Scotland but also
those of Ireland resorted to finish their
military training. Here it is said a woman
of the name of Scatach ro Sgiathach
taught such feats of arms as she alone could
teach. Irish historians maintain
that it was to this place Cuthuillin was
sent where he left his son Connlaoch
Within a few miles of Dunvegain are
the ruins of the college for pio pipe
music. Here the celebrated Mac
Cruimeins taught pipe music to many
pupils during many years.

In again was the Bardic
College – an Sgoil BhardacBhardachd taught
by the famous bards and historians
the Mac mhuirichs. In a historical
tale just now before me it is said these
Clann Mhuirich were in the yearly
habit of going to Ireland to collect a
cess of which was laid on every
family in Ireland and Scotland for
their maintainance.

The Rev Mar Mac Nicol Liosmore who so power
fully annihilated many of the exaggeration
and extortions advanced by Dr Johnson
collected a great many Gaelic M.S.S.
and M.S.S treating of Hi Gaelic matters.
One of his sons Captain Mac Nicol
of the RegtRegiment added largely to his fathers
collections. These he son highly valued that
wherever he went he brought them with
him. Unfortunately this his very care over
them proved their ultimate loss. In landing
from at in the W.West Indies from the
transport ship the boat in which he and his
brother officers were was capzised in the surf
and all the luggage was immediately carried
away by the strong tide while the officers were
barely rescued from a water grave. Among
many valuables lost was Captain
MacNicols large portmanteau of
Gaelic M.S.S. His sister Mrs Cameron
told me that she often afterwards heard her brother
bitterly lament the irreparable loss of the
M.S.S. that he regard although he lost
every thing also he had in the world he re-
garded the loss as nothing compared
with the loss of the M.S.S.

And the person of paramount
importance among the ancient High
landers was the Smith. Indeed so great
the veneration in which he is supposed
to have been held that he is believed to have
been held sacred by them. Like the bard an
seanachiseanachaidh the Smith seems to have been
a distinguised person in a chiefs
retinue. Land was conferred upon him
and like these he was freeexempt
from service in time of war. There are
many places in the Highlands named
after the Smith. There is a farm in Liosmore
called Baile-nan-gobhan Smiths' town. There
is a Baile-ghobhan in Lorn near Oban
and there is an island in Loch Seilleach
called Eilean bhaile nan gobhan and there
is a Baile nan gobhan in Ross shire.

The bard – which is supossed believed by
Capt Donald Campbell a most dis-
tinguished Gaelic philologist to be an con
traction of bi life and ard high – had great
influence over the polity of the Celts. In
time of peace he sung the people their songs
of enjoyment and prosperity and in times
of war in incited them to battle. There is
a very remarkable war song in the Rep.Repertoire of the Highlands society. This war song was communicated by the Rev. Mr Gallie. It is also in Smith's Sean Dana. It was learned by him along with other pieces
of merit from the M.S.S. in Mr MacPhersons
possession when translating OssOssian's poems.
It is remarkable for its elegance of
versification no less than its fierce-
ness of sentiment. Here it is:

lg.l: Cursan=Courser A mhacain cheann

"Is tu an
cursair
is a comcomplementary
term appdapplied to a tough
bustling woman Nan cursan strann
Ard leumnach righ nan sleagh s
Lamh threun 's gach cas
Cridh ard gun sgasgath
Ceann airm nan caoin gun goirt
Gearr sios gu bas
Gun bharc sheol ban
Dhi snamh mu dhugh Innse-torc
Mar thairneineach bhaoil
Do bhuile a laoich
Do shuil mar chaoir a d' cheann
Mar charraig chuinne
Do chridh gun roinn
Mar lasan oicheoidhche do lann
Cuir fuar do sgiasgiath
Is crobhuicrobhuidh nial
Mar chrith o reul a bhais
A mhacain cheann
Nan cursan strann
Sgrios naimhdean sios gu lailaigh

div.p:
So great was the power of the bards
over the minds of the people that at
at council of chiefs held at Iona in
it was enacted that any chief should be
fined for entertaining a bard. We we
amy well belived that neither chiefs nor
people long submitted to an act so much
at variance with their own sentiments
Again in by order of Edward the First
of England and the Welsh bards were mas-
sacred because the King he felt that they
were inimical to this own unprincipled merciless
policy. In Ireland matters were not
much better.

Some are for maintaining that the
kilt is but a modern dress. It is strange how
what ready credence anything demtrdemonstrated to the HighHighlands
is received. However imtive distorted the facts and uniform
ed the story if it makes against the HighHighlands
it receives easy credence. And on the
other hand again any thing said as
an antidote to this however respectable
the authority and well confined is
received with distrust.

There are many indisputable facts
that confirms the antiquity of the
kilt. There is an abbey in the Island
of Harris which is believed to be one of the
oldest pieces of architectural remains
in Scotland. The abbey is called Staint
Clemens = "Cill-a-Chliamain."
Among curious figures on the
tow tower of this old abbey is a sculp-
tured figure of a Highlander. The
dress is exactly like that worn at the
present day. The kilt comes to the
cap of the knee a while all the rest of
the dress corresponds with that now worn.
Another impression is that tartan or
is not old. This is another erroneous
impression. Tartan is old. In a Gaelic
M.S. of the 10th century the term breacan
literally chequered tartan is expressly
used. It is some what strange that
the English should pronounce the word
plaid more like the original GGaelic pronounci
ation than the Scotch do. The English
pronounce the word as if written plad
while the Scotch pronounce it according
to the orthography. The original of the
the word was plaide now confined
to the blanket. In ancient times when the
Highlanders were more given to hunt-
ing and fishing and battles and
perchance to creach lifting than they
are today their plaids joined their
blankets. Rolled up on these they slept securely
their bed the brown purple heathheather and their curtains
the their blueazure vaults of heaven.

There were four professions which were
of paromount importance among
the ancient Highlanders. These
were the armourer or Smith the
senachaidh or historian the musician
and the bard. There was another pro-
fession but I am not quite sure whether
or not it came down to recent times – I mean
military training. It may cause
in be new to some to hear that military
tactics of old was carried to great perfections
among the Highlanders. But indeed it
would be strange if people whose dispo-
sitions are so essentially military did
not pay some attention to this military
tactics training. The

It is no small honour to
that one of its beautiful daughters
inspired some of the most elegant
effusions of which the Gaelic muse
can boast. Any language might be
proud and and any lady delighted with
such soul dissolving stains as –
Feasgar Luain 'us mi air chuairt
and Cuachag nan craobh

The armourer was a man of much
importance among the H-Highlanders. In very early
times he made their spears and swords.
These I have no doubt were sufficiently
crude and primitive in finish and
design. But the handsarms which wielded
were strong and the hearts which
impelled them on were brave
But they were wielded by strong arms
and impelled by strong brave hearts and doubt-
less they as dear to their foes as they
were welcome to ther friends.

The seanchaidh or tale-teller was attached
to every house of any pretentions. He re-
counted the genealogy of the family
the battles of the clan and the
The ballads that are still floating
through the country and which are
now fast dying out an are of cons
iderable merit. Some of them are
contain stanzas of great beauty. But these
ballads were written only composed in imitation of others.
The excellence ofto which they were far from could not
attaining. After Burns shined a meteor
of dazzaling brilliancy a host of imitations
appeared and although some of them
were poets of considerable merits and
sweetness none of them were able to ap-
proach their original. After Scott
and Campbell and Byron many
others arose to imitate these and althoalthough
some of them have met with success and
applause their works will be entirely
forgotten where Scott still will delight
Campbell will still elevate and Byron
will still breath in words that burn. So
of all the host of ballads which were written
in imitation of Ossian the none of them
were able to approach their great original.
Some of them are beautiful good some
of them are beautiful some of them
are excellent but none of they have not
Ossians stamp upon them.

lg.l:
"Within that charmèd ch circle
None dared walk but he."

div.p:
Some of the poets take up similes from
one another and polish these as a lapidary
would a gem and make them their own.
AlexAlexander MacDonald said

lg.l: Do mhuineal geal boidheach
Mu'n iathadh an t-omar
A dha'dhath fein air gach seorsa
Chit a dortadh tre d' bhraghad

div.p:
But MacKenzie improved on this
and said in still more elegant lang.language

lg.l: Chit am fion a dearsa
An am dol sios tre d' bhraghad
S mar ealeala a snamhain saile
Tha cunnaibh graidh na h-ainnire

div.p: AlexAlexander MacDonald says

lg.l: Tha deirg agus gile
Gleac an gruaidhean na fine
Beul min man t-siris
O milis thaig gaire

div.p: But Ross more beautifully says

lg.l: Tha deirg us gile co mhire
Co mhire gleacanaich
Na gnuis ghil eibhinn
Rim ceudan airsneulach.

div.p:
The cause of the unhappy StuStuart
kings produced some fo the finest
Gaelic songs in the language. It was
the same in the LowLowland Scots. It is singular
that, as far as knowknown to me, there is not
a song of merit in behalf of the HanoHanoverians
How diffirent with the Stuarts! Witness

lg.l: Ach a Thearlaich oig StiuartStiubhart
Si do chuis rinn mo leireadh
Cha do dh-fagdh-fhag thu ni agam
Ann an cogadh a d-aobhar

div.p:
The Gaelic bard always drew his
images from Nature and hence they
were always natural. He looked around
on broad nature and therefrom drew
his similes. Did he wish to potray
the excellence of his lady love? The
New skin was whitewhiter than snow on the
mountain crest than the sawn of on the
silvery lake than the foam on the sea
beat shore on the mountain down.
Her hair was like the waving golden clouds
of the mountain or the golden sun beams
on the water or like the plumage of the
raven or the golden crested eagle
"Like raven's plumage smoothed on snow."
Her eyes were like stars at night where all
else was dark or like berries on the angles
of the precipeices on
Her cheeks were like budding roses
under the morning dew on the rowan
being in the evening sun. The ankles –
by no means an unessential part of
formal symmetry were like the salmon
of linn. Here steps were like the stately
steps of the mountain monarch stand
her movement graceful of as those
of the swan on the bosom of the silvery
lake.

Fletcher Scott of Saulton said Let me com
p unite the ballads of a nation and I care
not who write her history. It is very
sure that the poetry of a nation is a better
creation of the mind of a nation than any
thing else besides. The popular ballads
and songs of a nation may be taken
as the nations mind. I think therefore
the poetry of the H-Highlanders may be accepted as
a creation of the H-Highlanders mind. And a
person studying this poetry would
I doubt not get an insight into
H-Highlanders manners habits and taste better than
by studying the most elaborate HHighlander history
of the Highlands. In these we see their
love for the chase and military life their
appreciation of the wild and majestic
in Nature on which the bards often divert
with devoted fondness. We see their de-
votion to their chiefs their pride in the
noble deeds of their own clan ay and
their very weaknesses their credulity
and superstitions. There are how-
ever many who take no interest in these
things and these estimable people. But
there are also many who take no interest
in anything beyond their own immediate
necessities. There are men whose necessity
cont concentration of self prevents them
seeing beauty or utility aught else besides. There
are men who see neither beauty
nor utility in anything except the beauty
and utility of their own selfishness.
The glory of the sun the shining of
the monmoon the twinkling of the stars
createwaken within them no feelings of grati-
tude no sentiments of admiration.
The kindliest act of human nay of
divine nature are to these a thing of ordinary
occurrence. In the gilded
sky they see nothing but clouds in the
phosphoric ocean nothing but water.
Mountains glens and woods have no
hold upon their sympathies no dwell-
ing within their hearts. The song of the
mellow thrush is but noise in their
ears that of the skylark harshness while
the merry laugh of children brings them no
voice of gladness. But these pecularly
constituted beings are more to be
pitied than blamed – it is more their
misfortune than their fault.
I have little doubt but an interesting his-
tory could be written from the poetry of a
nation even if all other documents
were lost. And perhaps without mis
to be at all invidious the poetry of SotScotland
both in Gaelic and broad Scots could supply
this as well as they that of any other
nation under the sun. Some of the
most beautiful sciences are built upon
similar suppusitions. The geologist
disentombs bones from the bowels of the earth.
bones and skeletons These he clothes with
flesh and brings them to life and fixes their
era in the great changes of Nature.
From a single bone he determines what
ever their habits when they lived nay and
upon what they lived. The historian when
all other sources fail him has recourse
to the coins of a realm and therefore
constructs his history. The stone
breaker on the road side little thinks that the
spar under nearth his hammer is good
for no other purpose than mending
the road but the geometer can tell him that
that piece of seemingly worthless spar
is capable of exhibiting some of the
most wonderful and complex phenol
mena in nature. A person unac-
quainted with chemistry can hardly con
ceive of that a poundgiven quantity of tattered rags is capable
of producing more than a pound an increased quantity of refined
sugar. The sawyer who earns his bread
by the sweat of his brow can hardly believe
that the saw-dust he tramples under
neath his feet is capable of conversion
into what is to him and to us all a
matter of the utmost importance –
wholesome and ti nutritious bread.
Thompson says – "When beauty's unadorned
Her adorned the most."
But William Ross expressed the same idea in Gaelic before him –

lg.l: Gun innleacinnleachd bah ach buadh naduir
A toirt barr dhuit gun uaill.

div.p:
My aim is not to bring before you an in
finite number coincidences between
poets although this might do but simp-
ly to shew you that these coincidences
often happen among poets of un-
questionable talents and reputation.
Byron in his Childe Harold says

lg.l: Remove that Skull from out the scattered heap

div.p:
But the first regligiousreligious GaGaelic popoet D.Dugald Buchanan
said this before Byron.

lg.l: Mi am shuidh aig an uaigh
S mi coimhead mu'n cuairt
Feuch claigean gun snuagh nam lamh.

div.p:
Other poets have written perhaps more
powerfully than Ross but the love stricken
youth when under the bane of melancholy
hopelessness sorrow and despair will turn to Ross
for fitting language to express his
feelings. Of lyrical Gaelic poets he is
undoubtedly the first and a cycle of
years may come before before the Gaelic
language shall be again adorned with such
elegant such passionate and soul-
desolving strains. again

lg.l: Oh! unhappy fate country
Oh! unhappy bard
Hers
His the met reward

Sir WWalter Scott is deemed and original writwriter
True he is original as far as the fabric
of his buildings is concerned. But the ma-
terials he procured. He was in literature
what he was again in building his romance
in lime and stone – Abbotsford. These stones
was brought from every where to rear the fairy
fabric. CornicCornice from this frieze from that.
Every one who is at all acquainted with
G.Gaelic poetic literature knows how much
SSir WWalter Scott borrowed from these. It must
however be confessed that it is no easy task
to unravel the beautiful skein into which
he spun his G.Gaelic materials. The old and the
new are made to fit so beautifully as to
appear one whole. Still we can say of him
as an eldery lady who gave him many
similar things said to him when he was
denying to be that he was not the
authorship of the WWaverly Novels. What! Deny
ing it to my face? Do you think I do not
ken my ain groats among other peoples
kail! Highlanders complain and per-
haps with justice that SSir WWalter SScott does them
but scant justice. But H-Highlanders ought
to remember that when SSir WWalter SScott then was
a strong tide of prejudice remaing a-
gainst them. Their fathers had started
the British isles out of their propriety
in Within the memory of people then living
and as invariably the case on the
losing side they were sorely con-
demned. Did you ever see a rider
crossing a flooded river? He does
not try to go against the stream only
he does not even try to fairly cross
the stream knowing how dangerous
this would be to his own safety – he
He goes with the stream crosses ob-
liquely and lands on the other side
Such did SSir WWalter SScott to the Highlands

Poets like lapidaries. They get
hold of a gem no matter from whomhow or where
or when and make it their own.
and they polish and shape it to suit their
own tastes. It was once fixed in a brooch
it is now in a necklace. It once confined
the modest folds of a village maiden
it is polished reset and now adorns
the snowy bosom of a courtly countess.

A king was upon the throne and
although to his abominable vices
and those of the Stewarts would not
make a modest footstool he must
he and his progenitors must be lauded
andwhile the poor Stewars and those who
espoused their cause must be tra-
duced in proportionably. This was the
state in which SSir Walter Scott found
matters when he wrote. Thus
illustrating the Irish adage –
Am fear tha shuas buailtear biosair
Am fear ta shios buailtear cas air

Of topographical names
it can be said that they are most
ly Gaelic. Ardnamurchan –
is not the hight – a place well known
to those are apt to be sea sick
does not mean "the height of the
great oceans" but the height of
the mermaids. Muireach or
Murichan being an ancient by
name for a mermaid

A long time ago a Lewis boat
was out at when a Norwegian
vessel came upon them and
brought them away. The people
of that boat kept by themselves
and their languages still spoken
by their descendants still

lg.l: Tha maise caise s finealtacfinealtachd
A stri co dhiudhiubh is dilse dhuit
Tha ailleacailleachd gradh is fiunnteacfiughantachd
Cois tri riut air gach laimh –

div.p:
I have no wish to make invidious
remarks but I would not say against
my own convictions. I would not
bown down at the shrine of a star
and worship that star because it hap
pened to be om the ascedant.
And ride the air on whirlwind PParadise Lost p. 47 See Salad for the Social

It is mind not matter that rules
the universe. The Marquis of Westminster
shall be forgotten when the fame of Farady shall
shall shine on ages yet to come dazzle like lightning in the gloom bright as the meridian sun.
The LLong Island is a mine of antiquities mental
and material.

The grazier looksviews the grass simply
as food for his cattle. He sees not that beauty is
combined with utility elegance with vitality and
adaptation withal. He sees no beauty in its
leaves no no arrangements in its structure no
elegancegrace in its symmetry nor that "Ilka blade
o grass has its aim drap o dew."

The mariner sees nothing in the gilded
sky but a star to guide him on his course and
a moon light him to his haven. He does not see the
shores and shores of stars that co crowd
around the milky-way nor does he hear
the music of the spheres" ever singing
in unity but in uniformity a hallehallelujah
in praise of him Him who ordered
all things wisely and well. He hears
not the sonerous hosanna of the ocean the rapemelo
dy of the stars for ever singing as they shine
nor the glorious hallelujah of all unity but
though not in uniformity in prace of Him
who ordered all things wisely and well.
The mere material man looks not be
yond the material universe. He hears
not the music of the spheres the sonorous
hosannahs of the ocean and while the feathered cre-
ationchorus sing to him in vain

The stone breaker on the road side thinks
that the spade underneath his hammer is good
for no other purpose that mending the road
but the geometry can tell him that that lair
piece of seemingly worthless span is capable
of exhibiting some of the most wonderful
and complex phenenomena in creation That more unpromissing than
soot and yet what a beautiful
snowy powder it is construed!
into the shape of magnesia!
so is lime It is converted
into a most useful medicine
choloroform.
The whole whole creation praise the Creator
{butwhile man – estranged man – alone is mute.
True we have no gorgeous marble temples
no coleseums no pyramids among us but
we have in ingeniously contructed cyclopean underground
house religious temples strongly unique built duns
barps and castles all sand sculpted stones
all indicating that although the ori
ginators may have been more rude they could
have been no wakling fools. All these are fast
disappearing not so much by the wide beath breadth
of age as by the wider learedlearned opinion. And
this is likely to continue till the Highland proprietors
but we have cyclopedean underground houses
perched crannagoes ponderous monu
mental pillars ingeneously constructed duns
massive castel curiously wrought sculptured
stones and Druidical and Christian temples all
indicating that though the originators of these
may have been rude they could have been no
weakling fools.

div.p:
Heard this from John Stewart at
Bailshear who died 1868 78 age.

This John Stewart had a great store
of old things. He headheard of my search for old
things and often regtregretted that I was not comgcoming
the way so that he might unburdunburden his
mind to me ere he died. I never saw
him althoalthough I often wished.

When the Morair Bàn was in life
he used to come oftoften to N.North Uist and mingle with
the people. He spoke GGaelic. He asked an old
intelligintilligent man namnamed Gillean mac
Gillean after sermon to come with
him for a stroll to see the Temple at CairCairinish
All the people folldfollowed. He then asked him
how long since temple was built. 476. He
loktlooked in a red book in pocket & said this was so.
The buildbuilder was the second wife of the MacDonMacDonald
of the day daughtdaughter of MacDugall of Lorn.
Built TempulTeampul Chairinis Tempul
See p 20

Cladh MhartainMhartainn

Cladh Pheadair at Sollas house on top
of Well west side of 100 ydsyards.

div.title: An t each ursunn
div.p:
Sir Seumas RuaRuadh lived in Sollas
and had a housecaisteal there{the ruins of this
were taken down abtabout 780 yrsyears ago for fear
thethey would injure cattle & horses that
used to shelter there. They were higher than
Carinish temple. When taken down
they nearly killdkilled several. The pillars would
sway to & fro like trees. An anchor was pldplaced
at a distance and a cable on the top
tier of the binneag & then taken down.
This was Caisteal Shollais. CCaisteal SheumSheumais
RuaiRuaidh. Sir Seumas RuaRuadh was marmarried
twice. Had a son by the first wife also
Seumas Og. A Maor mor came frfrom
Trotarnish to take up the Each Ursann.
He went to Baileshear and took one the
best was the E-ursannEach-ursann and taod gaosgaoisid
aid frfrom a poor widwidow there He came to
Sollas heated in a warm day. He
stooped to drink of out of Tobar
Pheadair and Seumas og saw
him and rushdrushed out with his swdsword
Take up yryour bonbonnet said he and put
it on yryour hedhead and be off and never
let me see yryour face here again or
Ill cut yryour head into that well
His muimmuime heavy with child came
betwbetween them and S.Seumas Og said I give him
his life not for his own lifeless car
cass but frfor your sake but let me
never see his face again. The Maor
mor ran off as hard as he cldcould anand
no maor has ever come frfrom Trot
airnis since to N.North Uist. Tobar
Pheadair was closed there after
that and opdopened 30 ydsyards lower down.

div.p:
AbtAbout 100 yrsyears ago a man gtgreat gradgrand father of
DonlDonald BhoradhaiBhoradhaidh saw an eagle comcoming
frfrom Heusger with a lamb in its claws. He
had a horse halter in his hand & threw it up
at the eagle which dropdropped the lamb at the
mans feet. The lamb's ear was bleeding
but otherwise uninjured. The man
took it up brotbrought it him and it begbeing a female
it grew up and was the progprogenitor of a flock
of sheep.

UistMhic Uistein an nocnochd SlairiSlabhraidh & nocnochd
At one time a band of tinkers frfrom Lewis

The seals took themselthemselves off and for sevseveral

night the best haul was got after this
Many cob to GrimGriminish to a ball on St MichMicheil's
They got warnwarning and said they would try HHaisgeir

AobharAdhbhar si bean uasal og an rinn an t oran agus
bha i muigh sa gharagharadh lios aig a
h-athar agus co thainig an rathad
ach siichsithich briabriagh. Bhid ela cheanlathaichean
a tachtathaich orra agus e air muin
each glas agus la cheanlathaichean eileile
ga choischoiseachd. Bhi e toirt coinecoinneachadh dha
mu mheadhon lalatha. Bha a so
a piuthar a cur aireacaithearachd orra agus
bhi e falafalbh coir LaLatha bha sin
agus dh fhalbh ise na ruiruith agus
dh fhag i sidsiod i. Cha b urrb urrainn i fuirfuireach
Cheas a sin a piuarpiuthar i agus
gheall i nach tigtigeadh a deoch a
mach air a beul gus an tigtigeadh e an
toistoiseach a mach air a beulglun. Thuirt
an SithSithich rithse gun inseinnseadh a piuarpiuthar
e ga brarienbriathran agus gu maradhmarbhadh iad
easan Rinn a piuarpiuthar so agus
loisg iadsan airgiod air agus
mharbh iad e agus bhasaich
ise leis a mhulad.

div.add:
Heard this from an old woman
a Catherine MacDonald
She could read the bible – a
most unusual thing in those days She
was about 80 years. There was no Gaeilc
bible in the country then. In those days
men used to shoot on Sunday.
Every man brotbroughut his gun to church
after the service was over they took
their guns off to shoot. The Mon
day after the communion was
the fair for all goods to sell.

div.p:
There is in possession of Mr Roderick
MacLellan Bahiarva Barra a pipe that
belonged at one time to Prince Charlie. It
is made of light coloured wood like boxwood
and mounted with ebony and dotted all
over with ebony like pin points. Upon the
gaothaire or mouthpiece were dotted in
ebony the initials "Pr.PrinceC.CharlesE.EdwardS.Stuart" and the year
"1744". showing that Prince Charlie
was evidently preparing himself for con
ciliating the Highlanders by qualify-
ing himself to play their national music
al instrument. Upon the changer
are still visible the letter H.HughB.Brown the
initials of Hugh Brown piper to his
Royal Highness. Mr MacLellan sent
the gaothaire to Glasgow some years ago
for repair. The man by whom he sent it
had also a box of eggs. These he began
to dispose of on his arrival at the
Broomielaw. The mouthpiece was ly-
ing in the shottle of the chest and while the
Barra man was busy disposing of
his eggs the mouthpiece was stolen to the
Barra man's discomfiture and Mr
MacLellan's great regret. How the pipe
came into Mr MacLellans hands was this –
Hugh Brown was Piper to the Prince and
always about his person. After At Culloden
Hugh got separated from his Royal master
and never managed to see him again.
There were many things belonging to the
Prince in his possession. He skulked
about like so many others after Culloden.
He then married and settled down
and at last made his way to Canada
where he married and settled down. Mr
MacLellan had a brother who was a seafar
ing man who in his travels in Canada
became acquainted with a grand-
daughter of this Hugh Brown. among other
things a silver cup or tankard a cup
and saucer sent from Ormacleit
to the Prince while living in the cave at
Corrodale. These and several other
relicts of the Prince MacLellan
had and valued them highly. He was
lost at sea and all his property lost. The
pipe was the only thing probably because
it was inconvertible with cash that was
found in his lodgings in Liverpool
after his death. MacLellan
valued these things so much that he used
to carry them with him in the ship so the
things are supposed to have been lost with him.

Mathair ealanta nighean fhinealta
Is fearr buaidh le neart ceart na buaidh le ceartceneart
Who overcomes by force over comes but

There is a cave on the Milton
farm where the Prince lived for
a time and a stone near by upon which
a girl used to leave his food for
him. When the Prince came
to Milton to see Flora MacDonald
he sat outside the house
while went in to speak
to the young lady. The servant
seeing a stranger sitting near
the house went to look at him.
The stone is still pointed out
as Clach a Phrionnsa
